channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.N. Report on Gaza Finds Evidence of War Crimes by Israel and by Palestinian Militants
item.description: The report said “impunity prevails across the board” regarding the actions of Israeli forces in Gaza, but also cited the “inherently indiscriminate nature” of rockets fired at Israeli civilians.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinian houses destroyed by Israeli shelling in Beit Hanoun in the Gaza Strip in 2014.

item.title: Gangi Journal: Sicilian Town Tells Outsiders: Take Our Homes. Please.
item.description: To reverse their town’s loss of population, residents of Gangi are offering houses for free or for nominal prices, provided that the new owners fix them.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: The historic center of Gangi, a Sicilian town whose local administration is giving away abandoned houses. The giveaway is a means to stimulate tourism-related activities and diversify the local economy, which is now primarily dependent on agriculture and animal husbandry.

item.title: Taliban Attack Afghan Parliament and Seize a Second District in North
item.description: No serious injuries were reported in the Parliament attack, which occurred as lawmakers gathered for a third attempt to confirm a defense minister.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: The site of a Taliban attack outside the Afghan Parliament in Kabul on Monday.

item.title: Russia Assails Extension of E.U. Sanctions in Ukraine Crisis
item.description: Kremlin officials, who had lobbied hard against an extension, called it self-defeating and said their countersanctions would be extended in response.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Al Jazeera Journalist Is Released by Germany
item.description: The detention at a Berlin airport of Ahmed Mansour, 52, the subject of an Egyptian arrest warrant, had prompted a wave of protest.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Greece Offers New Debt Plan, but Creditors Want Time to Study It
item.description: Athens delivered a raft of proposals to its creditors, but eurozone finance ministers met without reaching an agreement on a debt deal.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Jean-Claude Juncker, right, the European Commission president, gave Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece a friendly slap on Monday at an impromptu joint news conference.

item.title: Leaders of South Korea and Japan Speak of Improving Ties
item.description: An exchange of conciliatory remarks came as the officials observed the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations at embassy events in their respective capitals.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: South Korean Retailers Pinched by MERS
item.description: The outbreak has scared away enough foreign tourists and domestic consumers for the government to worry about its effect on the economy.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Indonesia Rejects Appeal by French Drug Convict on Death Row
item.description: The decision clears the way for an execution as soon as July and risks global outrage over Indonesia’s use of capital punishment for drug crimes.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY HUTTON
item.media:description: Serge Atlaoui, center, a French citizen who is on death row after being convicted of drug offenses, at the district court in Tangerang, Indonesia, in March.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Study Maps Concentrations of Antibiotics in Chinese Waterways
item.description: Rivers near Beijing and Tianjin in the north and in the Pearl River Delta in the south contain some of the highest concentrations of antibiotics in China’s waterways.
item.dc:creator: CHERIE CHAN
item.media:description: Fishing the Hai River in Tianjin, a waterway with one of the highest levels of antibiotics in China, researchers say.

item.title: Nun in Central India Is Sexually Assaulted
item.description: The attack occurred after two masked assailants jumped a fence to enter a medical center, the police in Chhattisgarh State said.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Few Echo Pope’s Environment Plea in Sunday Sermons
item.description: Around the world, few priests used their pulpits on Sunday to pass on the pope’s message on climate change, pollution and global inequality.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Pope Francis visited Turin, Italy, on Sunday, as some priests around the world preached his message on climate change, pollution and inequality.

item.title: Charles Correa, 84, Is Dead; Architect Fused India’s History With Modernism
item.description: Mr. Correa, whose works were notable for their imagination and breadth, created striking museums and university buildings in India and abroad and was deeply invested in India’s urban future.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Fissures in E.U. Deepen From Strain of Migrant Influx and Greek Debt
item.description: A sense of disarray has surrounded the 28-nation bloc as it grapples simultaneously with two crises: a wave of desperate migrants fleeing war and poverty, and the prospect that Greece may default.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Protesters waved flags and held a banner reading "Slovakia Is Not Africa" during an anti-immigration rally in Bratislava, Slovakia.

item.title: Archive of Captured Enemy Documents Closes
item.description: The documents included detailed records of Saddam Hussein’s high command in Iraq and Qaeda records from Afghanistan; Pentagon officials say they are planning to transfer the archive to a civilian institution.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: International Yoga Day Finally Arrives in India, Amid Cheers and Skepticism
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government attempted to give new life to the idea that yoga can help restore national pride and a return to ancient values could help illness.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India led participants during a demonstration in New Delhi on Sunday for the inaugural International Yoga Day.

item.title: Macedonia Government Is Blamed for Wiretapping Scandal
item.description: According to a European Commission report, the national security service acted on orders from the government. The prime minister reacted defiantly.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Netanyahu Rebuffs France on Restarting Mideast Talks
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said the international efforts failed to address his country’s security needs and other national interests.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius of France, left, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem on Sunday.

item.title: Memo From Afghanistan: Taliban Are Talking Peace, Though Not With Afghan Government
item.description: As they make battlefield gains, the insurgents are engaged in peace talks and showing signs of moving away from some of their hard-line stances.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: The Taliban have met with female activists, including Shukria Barakzai, left, an Afghan lawmaker.

item.title: Taliban and Afghan Government Dispute Status of Kunduz
item.description: Taliban insurgents said Sunday that they were on the verge of taking their first Afghan city, Kunduz. But the central government said there was no cause for concern.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
